ygData.msgSnippet: Ulf, At high strain rates, it becomes more difficult to find a solution. Often it is possible to find a solution by starting with a solution at a lower strain

Ulf,

At high strain rates, it becomes more difficult to find a solution.   
Often it is possible to find a solution by starting with a solution at  
a lower strain rate, and progressively solving problems with slightly  
higher strain rates. If it still fails, take smaller increments in  
strain rate. If it *still* fails, it may be that the solution is  
changing character - for example, the flame may be extinguishing.

Note that Cantera's grid refinement procedure includes a 'prune' option  
to remove grid points that are no longer needed. This is important in  
problems like this, since the flame location moves as the strain rate  
increases.  By setting the prune parameter to a small non-zero value  
(say 0.05) you can keep the total number of grid points reasonable as  
the flame front shifts.

Dave


On Mar 9, 2004, at 8:11 AM, usenechal wrote:

> Dear Prof. Goodwin,
>
> when I try to simulate a counterflow flame with higher strainrates
> (high massflows) I get errors like:
>
> -----------------------------------------------
> Traceback (most recent call last):
>   File "C:\Work\Nrs\Cantera-OneDim\npflame1.py", line 132, in  
> -toplevel-
>     u = f.u()
>   File
> "C:\PROGRA~1\Python23\lib\site-packages\Cantera\OneD\CounterFlame.py",
> line 172, in u
>     return self.solution('u', point)
>   File
> "C:\PROGRA~1\Python23\lib\site-packages\Cantera\OneD\CounterFlame.py",
> line 184, in solution
>     else: return self.profile(self.flame, component)
>   File
> "C:\PROGRA~1\Python23\lib\site-packages\Cantera\OneD\onedim.py", line
> 431, in profile
>     x[n] = self.value(domain, component, n)
>   File
> "C:\PROGRA~1\Python23\lib\site-packages\Cantera\OneD\onedim.py", line
> 425, in value
>     return _cantera.sim1D_value(self._hndl, idom, icomp, localPoint)
> error:
> Procedure: Sim1D::newtonSolve

> -------------------------------------------
>
> I guess it's a problem of the solution method ? What can I do ? Can I
> switch to a transient simulation in python ?
>
> best regards
> ulf
